Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Highly reactive thiol binding sites on bacterial cell envelopes and their influence on metal speciation in aquatic systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria are ubiquitous in natural environments. The adherence of metal ions onto the surface of bacterial cells can affect the global cycling of elements, the mobility of metal contaminants, and the effectiveness of contaminant mitigation techniques. Past studies have identified the importance of certain bacterial surface sites in adhering metal ions at unrealistically high metal concentrations. However, recent studies suggest that at environmentally relevant metal concentrations, previously unrecognized sites may be more important. The goal of this study is to better understand the impact of high-affinity, but low abundance, bacterial surface binding sites on metal uptake and reactivity in aquatic systems. Because most metals are present at low concentrations both in natural and contaminated systems, the outcomes of this research could help better understand the environmental fate of heavy metals in natural environments.

An innovative approach will be used to isolate the influence of R-SH sites on bacterial cell envelopes. Specifically, an R-SH-sensitive fluorophore molecule (qBBr) will be used that binds strongly to R-SH sites on the cell envelope. qBBr fluoresces when bound to R-SH sites, and the charge on the molecule prevents it crossing the cell membrane easily; and hence can be used for previously impossible direct determinations of R-SH site concentrations on cell envelopes. In addition, because qBBr binds so strongly to cell envelope R-SH sites, we can use it as a blocking agent in order to isolate proton- and metal-binding reactions with cell envelope R-SH sites. The funded research will, for the first time, directly probe the role of cell envelope thiol sites, and will enable us to study their interactions with metals. Using fluorescence and x-ray absorption spectroscopies, coupled with potentiometric titration and bulk adsorption experiments, the PIs will measure the thiol concentration on cell envelopes of selected bacteria common to most aquatic systems, and to determine how different environmental variables, such as the growth medium and growth conditions (aerobic versus anaerobic) influence the thiol concentrations. The PIs will measure Zn adsorption onto thiol sites, and determine the molecular structures and binding constants of the Zn-thiol complexes on bacterial cell envelopes using sorption and spectroscopy approaches. The detailed measurements that the qBBr approach makes possible have the potential to transform our understanding of how bacteria bind metals under realistic conditions. The results of the proposed research are critical for evaluating the role of these important binding sites on metal speciation and distribution in the environment. The results from this study can be applied not only to contaminant transport modeling, but also to bioremediation engineering and to understanding heavy metal cycling in the environment in general.

The funded research will support a number of outreach activities, including teacher training through Princeton University?s ?Quest? program; the development of a geomicrobiology/environmental chemistry module in South Bend high school science research programs; and teaching a water pollution technology module in South Chicago-area high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the different reactive functional groups within bacterial cell envelopes, carboxyl and phosphoryl groups have been identified as important sites of metal binding under conditions of elevated metal concentrations. However, our recent studies document the importance of sulfhydryl sites as the primary bacterial cell envelope binding sites for Cd2+ and Hg2+ under low metal loading (nanomolar range). Many metals are present in sub-micromolar concentrations both in natural and several contaminated systems, and as shown in our studies, binding of chalcophile metals such as Zn, Cd, and Hg onto bacterial cell envelope sulfhydryl sites is likely to control the speciation, distribution, mobility, and bioavailability of these elements in aquatic systems. Therefore, it is crucial to determine the concentration, structure and reactivity of the sulfhydryl groups on bacterial cell envelopes in order to model the environmental fate of these heavy metals.  Our current understanding of these critically important binding sites is extremely limited. The goal of our study is to develop a quantitative and mechanistic understanding of the impact of bacterial sulfhydryl groups on bacterial metal uptake and speciation in aquatic systems.

 

This project involved research on a number of fronts. NSF could fund this proposal only at 50% of our originally proposed budget level, so we have limited the research projects that can be addressed during the lifetime of this award. We focused our attention on three of the key questions raised in our proposal: 1) How do growth conditions influence the concentration and structure of sulfhydryl sites on cell envelopes?, 2) What is the affinity of these sites for selected soft Lewis acids (e.g., Zn2+)?, and 3) How do the thermodynamic stabilities of these metal-sulfhydryl complexes on the cell envelope compare with those of Zn2+ complexes with aqueous small chain thiol-containing molecules (e.g. cysteine, glutathione) and with thiol sites in DOM?

 

Many of the studies within this project make use of an innovative approach to isolate the influence of sulfhydryl sites on bacterial cell envelopes. Specifically, we used a thiol-specific fluorophore molecule (qBBr) that binds strongly to sulfhydryl sites on the cell envelope. qBBr binds strongly and specifically only to cell envelope sulfhydryl sites, and our experiments made use of this feature by using qBBr as a blocking agent in order to isolate proton- and metal-binding reactions with cell envelope sulfhydryl sites. In one project, we conducted potentiometric titration experiments with and without qBBr blocking of sulfhydryl sites in order to determine the concentration of these sites on bacterial cell envelopes. By doing these tests on cells grown under different growth conditions, we have determined the effect of growth media on sulfhydryl site concentrations, finding a strong effect and potentially leading to engineered species capable of enhanced heavy metal removal from water. Other projects have used adsorption experiments to quantify the thermodynamic stability of metal-sulfhydryl complexes on the bacterial surface for the first time. Our data suggest that these binding constants involving sulfhydryl sites are orders of magnitude greater than corresponding binding constants involving non-sulfhydryl cell envelope sites, and suggesting the predominance of metal-sulfhydryl binding under low metal loading conditions despite the low abundance of sulfhydryl sites relative to other binding sites within the cell envelope.

 

Seven papers have been published, are in press, or are submitted as a result of the funded project. The following studies were either fully or partially funded by the NSF funds (graduate students or postdocs under my supervision are highlighted in italics):

 

Yu, Q., and Fein, J.B. (2017, submitted) Controls on bacterial cell envelope sulfhydryl site concentrations: The effect of glucose concentration during growth. Environmental Science and Technology.

 

Vázquez-Ortega A., and Fein J.B. (2017, in press) Thermodynamic modeling of Mn(II) adsorption onto manganese oxidizing bacteria. Chemical Geology.

 

Fein J.B. (2017) Advanced biotic ligand models: Using surface complexation modeling to quantify metal bioavailability to bacteria in geologic systems. Chemical Geology.

 

Nell, R.M., and Fein, J.B. (2017) Influence of sulfhydryl sites sites on metal 
binding by bacteria. Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta, 199, 210-221.

 

Yu, Q., and Fein, J.B. (2015) The effect of metal loading on Cd adsorption onto Shewanella oneidensis bacterial cell envelopes: The role of sulfhydryl sites. Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta 167, 1-10.

Yu, Q., and Fein, J.B. (2016) Sulfhydryl binding sites within bacterial extracellular polymeric substances. Environmental Science and Technology 50, 5498-5505.

Mishra, B., Shoenfelt, E., Yu, Q., Yee, N., Fein, J.B., and Myneni, S. (2017, in press) Stoichiometry of mercury-thiol complexes on bacterial cell envelopes. Chemical Geology.
